channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #202 - Perl 5.22 is now available
item.description:
Hi,

Perl 5.22 is out, in both regular and Strawberry flavours. Thanks and kudos to everyone who contributed, and to RJBS who brought it to us.

YAPC::NA starts today. I hope everyone there has a great time, and if you're not there, check the youtube channel

Many of us will also be thinking about GENEHACK this week, who won't be at YAPC::NA, because he's having surgery.

Editor #3, Neil
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: perl-5.22.0 is now available
item.description: Rik announced the latest major version of Perl 5, which has contributions from at least 102 people. Read perldelta to find out what's new, or read brian d foy's summary from a couple of months back.

item.title: Strawberry Perl 5.22
item.description: The Strawberry flavoured edition of Perl 5.22 is already available as well.

item.title: The velociraptor is dead, long live the velociraptor
item.description: Since 2010, Matt has been giving "State of the Velociraptor" talks at Perl events, covering what's new in Perl 5. He's now passed on the baton to Sawyer X, which seems like an excellent choice!

item.title: What's new on CPAN - May 2015
item.description: David's regular round-up of notable new modules on CPAN, including his new module of the month, which this time was App::GitHooks::Plugin::ForceBranchNamePattern.

item.title: Mojo::Snoo - alpha release
item.description: Curtis has created a wrapper around the reddit API, which curiously is called Mojo::Snoo.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Bounty for fixing CPAN modules
item.description: Gabor pointed out bountysource, a service where you can provide bounties for certain bugs. He wonders if we could use this to get bugs fixed in key distributions?

item.title: Testing and Validating HTML Templates
item.description: Kahlil shows us how he makes sure that his Catalyst applications always generate valid HTML.

item.title: Hubble, Bubble, Toil and Trouble: Catalyst, Bootstrap and HTML::FormFu
item.description: Kalhlil talks through getting Catalyst, Bootstrap and HTML::FormFu to play nicely together in your applications.

item.title: Using AngularJS with Perl backends
item.description: A presentation that JT gave to Madison Perl Mongers last month.

item.title: Diagnosing performance degradation under adverse circumstances
item.description: A war story from Mike, as he talks us through a performance issue they had on one page, and how they got to the bottom of it, with help from Devel::NYTProf.

item.title: Perl Golf at YAPC::Russia 2015
item.description: Andrew describes the Perl golf competition held at YAPC::Russia this year, and walks us through his solution.

item.title: Loopify Recursions
item.description: Helmut shows us how he eliminated recursion in his LCS module, to avoid the warning about too-deep recursion.

item.title: Learning Perl Challenge: Be better than Quorum
item.description: brian sets a simple challenge, which you have to write a Perl solution for in 5 minutes. Then a day later, write another solution from scratch, and see how your two solutions differ.

item.title: Act Voyager Report
item.description: An update from Theo on his ACT grant, and also on his new job in London!

item.title: Maintaining Perl 5: Grant Report for April 2015
item.description: In April Tony did 83.25 hours on Perl 5, during which time he worked on 40 different tickets.

item.title: Choose your YAPC Europe favourite talks
item.description: If you're going to YAPC::EU this year, please mark which talks you're interested in attending. This helps the organisers allocate talks to appropriately sized rooms, and lets you build a personalised schedule.

item.title: Jonathan's update
item.description: So first we all need to congratulate Jonathan on his nuptials. Oh, and he did some Perl 6 stuff too!

item.title: MonolithFirst
item.description: You're probably hearing a bit about microservices these days. Here Martin suggests that you should always start with a monolothic architecture, and only start breaking out microservices when you've got enough experience and understanding of the problem.

item.title: Feedback is a Gift
item.description: Andrew argues that when someone gives you, or your project, feedback, the only correct response is to say "thank you". I certainly need to do better on that score.
